title: Trudeau campaigns against non-candidate as he struggles in suburbs
text:
But his approval ratings have plummeted to around 26 percent since being elected last year — in part because of a series of cuts to popular education and social services including autism programs, along with controversies over his appointment of friends to high-paying government posts.

That’s given Liberals, who are struggling to hold onto their majority in next week’s federal elections, an opening. Ragging on Ford has become Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s favorite pastime.

Last week, he mentioned Ford seven times in about 30 minutes — equaling references to Conservative leader Andrew Scheer — during a campaign stop in Markham, a suburb in the Greater Toronto Area, or GTA. This bellwether battleground has about as many seats in Parliament as the entire province of Alberta, making it key to forming a majority government.

“Where is Doug Ford … bound and gagged somewhere? He hasn’t been seen in three months,” James Maloney, a Liberal candidate in Ford’s hometown of Etobicoke, joked during a debate last week.

Ford has not appeared alongside Scheer when the Conservative leader made major promises to invest in transit and make child care more affordable in the region.

Ford declined to be interviewed for this article, but during a press event on Wednesday, he dismissed Trudeau’s comments as politics.

“I think the guy loves me because he constantly is mentioning my name,” Ford added with a laugh.

“When it comes to Justin Trudeau, he has a race to run,” Ford said. “I’m focused on governing, very simple. I’m not focused on campaigning.”

Jenni Byrne, a longtime Conservative operative and former adviser to Ford, characterized Liberals’ taunting as “political theater.”

“I think people are reading into this much more than they should,“ Byrne said. “The provincial government has a ton of files that are hot. At the end of the day, I think [Ford] doesn’t care to be dragged into the federal campaign.“



Trudeau may be equally polarizing after his own recent controversies. Last month, he apologized for donning black-and-brownface as a student in the 1990s and as a private school teacher in 2001.

And in August, Canada’s ethics commissioner determined that Trudeau improperly tried to shield a top engineering company from criminal charges — known as the SNC-Lavalin affair. Then there is the prime minister’s divisive decision to purchase a $4.5 billion oil pipeline.

“My job is to make the law, not break the law,” Conservative challenger Barry O’Brien said during the debate in Etobicoke. Even his mentions of Scheer were few and far between.

Asked about whether Ford is a liability to his campaign, O’Brien pivoted to the province’s Liberal predecessor, Kathleen Wynne, whose party lost all but seven seats in provincial government elections last year. “People still remember that. And those who worked for Wynne are now working for Trudeau in Ottawa,” O’Brien told POLITICO.

The Trudeau vs. Ford proxy fight poses problems for both Liberals and Conservatives as they jockey for Toronto and the city’s fast-growing and multicultural suburbs. Interviews with two dozen voters of all ages and ethnic backgrounds reveal disillusionment with Trudeau, even as they express exasperation with Conservatives over Ford's policies.

A recent survey by the Angus Reid Institute found that 42 percent of Ontarians won’t vote for Scheer because of Ford. But Trudeau’s approval rating has continued to slip this year, which could easily lead to a minority government on Oct. 21.

The path to victory hinges on the 30 ridings surrounding Toronto that Trudeau swept in 2015, when young voters — exhilarated by his promises to legalize marijuana, tackle climate change and reform the electoral system — turned out in record numbers.

Multiple pit stops in the region by party leaders highlight its significance. Scheer pledged last week to fund two major transit projects, including one that would link Toronto to suburbs like Markham and Vaughn. Last Wednesday, Trudeau announced from a Chinese grocery store in Markham that his first act as a reelected prime minister would be tax cuts for the middle class.

Markham-Stouffville, where a former member of Trudeau’s Cabinet is running as an Independent, as well as Brampton East, where an NDP candidate is trying to beat the odds, will be crucial tests. Across the GTA, electoral projections by 338Canada indicate a neck-and-neck race between Liberals and Conservatives.



Jane Philpott, the now-Independent candidate in a mostly middle-class suburb, hopes to capitalize on the anti-Trudeau sentiment. After publicly denouncing the prime minister’s handling of the SNC-Lavalin affair earlier this year, she was ousted from the Liberal Party along with Jody Wilson-Raybould, Canada’s first Indigenous Minister of Justice, who is also running as an Independent in Vancouver.

“I think [Trudeau] and our whole team were elected on a wave of optimism and hope that things would be done differently,” Philpott told POLITICO during an interview in her campaign office in Stouffville, about 40 minutes northeast of Toronto bordered by farmland.

Philpott, a medical doctor by training, held numerous cabinet posts between 2015 and 2019. “There were some very important steps that were taken, like having a gender-balanced cabinet. But there have been disappointments.”

Trudeau has said he takes responsibility for mistakes he made, but disagrees with some of the ethics commission’s findings. He also defends his actions as standing up for Canadian jobs, because a conviction of SNC-Lavalin could mean a 10-year ban on federal contracts. The company is headquartered in Montreal, another political battleground, but half of its nearly 9,000 Canadian employees work outside the province, CBC reported earlier this year. Liberal candidates for MP are making a similar case to voters.

Philpott thinks the race is between her and Liberal candidate Helena Jaczek, based on a small poll her campaign commissioned this month that showed Conservative support far behind.

Jaczek, a former Ontario health minister who lost her seat last year amid the Ford wave, told POLITICO that this isn’t what she’s hearing at the doors. She decided to run because of an outpouring of calls from community and party leaders.

In either case, Philpott is telling voters that she is their best shot at booting Trudeau from power. She argued that the Conservatives have no chance of prevailing in the riding, so people who want to see Trudeau out of power should vote for her.

“Voting for me is a way to help Trudeau go. It means one less Liberal seat. The Conservatives aren’t going to win this seat,” Philpott told Fonce Blommesstyn, an older Dutch Canadian, after he pulled into his driveway.

“It’s not that I don’t want to vote for you. I’m fed up with Trudeau,” Blommesstyn said. “I’ve got only one choice, Trudeau or … .”

“Me!” Philpott interjected.

Helen Leon, 71, said she has voted for several different parties over the years and is supporting Philpott this cycle. Asked why it isn’t Conservatives: “I have enough of Doug Ford here. They get too vicious with their cuts.”

Ford last year canceled university expansions in three suburbs, including Markham and Brampton, to “restore trust and accountability in Ontario’s finances,” citing a C$15 billion deficit. (The province recently revised that figure to C$7.4 billion for 2018-19.)

The premier reduced public college tuition 10 percent but simultaneously slashed spending on a loan and grant program that helps students pay for school. The move effectively eliminated fully covered tuition for families earning less than $50,000 a year, although in general a greater percentage of low-income students will receive a mix of aid.

Just last week, tens of thousands of education workers in Ontario threatened to strike before reaching a deal with the Ford government, securing an extra C$100 million to support staff jobs and wage increases. This followed opposition to another Ford policy in March that increased classroom sizes over several years and led to teacher layoffs. The tussles have prompted a number of attack ads against the premier on the airwaves.

“Doug Ford says he’s ‘For the People,’ but he’s certainly not for our children and grandchildren,” Jerry Dias, national president of the union group Unifor, said in a radio ad zeroing in on education, which aired during peak commute hours.

The NDP candidate in Brampton East, Saranjit Singh, said Ford’s decision to cancel the university was “short-sighted.” But voters he talks to are just as frustrated with Trudeau’s party.

“When I ask people door-to-door, ‘What have Liberals done for you?’ most people will say nothing. Brampton has received nothing but cuts and neglect from the Liberals and the Conservatives,” Singh said, noting that residents felt that way despite having Liberal MPs and a majority government since 2015.

Singh is Sikh, just like Jagmeet Singh, the NDP party leader who previously represented Brampton at the provincial level. The suburb has one of the largest Sikh communities outside of India, on display by the shops in the strip mall where Saranjit Singh’s campaign office is located. Across the street is a bright white gurdwara, where Sikhs worship.

Singh, whose family immigrated to Canada in the 1980s through the refugee program and is now a labor lawyer, has an office humming with young volunteers, of which he has about 400.

Last week, 338Canada projected Singh in third place. Fast forward to Monday, and he jumped ahead of the Conservative, but still lags 16 points behind the Liberal candidate.

Singh echoes the NDP party leader in his pitch to progressive Canadians against strategic voting, hitting both Liberals and Conservatives. Strong action on climate change, reconciliation with Indigenous communities, and robust investments in affordable housing, transit and health care, won’t materialize under the two main parties, he said.

“If you vote for a party without looking at the candidate ... you risk our country not progressing. And that’s a really big risk,” Singh said.
